Award.AwardTitle: Robust Control of Uncertain Switched Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to develop systematic controller design tools for complex systems. The PIs will develop procedures for modeling the behavior of interest using a set of so-called uncertain affine models. Having a representation of the system in this standard form will then allow for the development of systematic robust controller design algorithms that enable controller synthesis with provable performance. Emphasis will be put not only on the development of theoretical results but also on using the proposed approach in concrete applications such as feedback control of epileptic seizures.

Intellectual Merit: The approach presented relies on the concept of uncertain switched systems. The proposed work will address several open problems in the area of switched systems and their connection to uncertain systems. Specifically, the proposed research will develop efficient methods that determine a set of affine models and the uncertainty bound that explain the observed nonlinear behavior, and tools for robust controller design for uncertain switched affine systems. The main advantages of the proposed approach, as compared to other approaches to controller design for complex systems, are: a) Robust system approximation procedures; b) Ability to design controllers with provable performance and, given enough computational resources, with performance arbitrarily close to the achievable optimum; c) Ability to design controllers for complex systems for which one does not have a global model but only local information is available.

Broader Impact.
The proposed activity explores the concept of covering complex dynamics by the set of dynamic behaviors of an uncertain switched affine model. It will lead to the development of systematic, problem-independent tools for controller design that can be used in a wide range of applications such as feedback control of epilepsy and other similar neurological disorders. Education is proactively integrated into this project through incorporation of nonlinear control in the undergraduate curriculum, a robotics course developed with particular emphasis on the nonlinear control aspects, REU supplements to motivate undergraduate students to pursue studies in nonlinear and hybrid control, and integration of the research outcomes into graduate course materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the proposed research is to develop systematic tools that can be used to analyze and control complex systems. The main concept underlying the proposed approach is switched systems, a "simple" dynamical system description that can be used to approximate the behavior of almost any complex system.

In this grant we achieved the following results

1) Tools were developed for the identification of switched system models. These tools rely on concepts form very different areas, such as control, machine learning and algebraic geometry to develop efficient numerical algorithms which can identify switched models from data collected.

 

2) Analyzing systems subject to uncertainty. Identified systems are always subject to uncertainty. Hence, to analyze them one needs tools that can efficiently compute risk. To this end, we have developed approaches that can provide efficient numerical estimates of the risk of not achieving the desired performances specifications both in the case where complete information on the probability distribution is available and in the cases where only partial information is available.

 

3) We have also designed efficient algorithms for controller design of switched systems. In the case of no uncertainty, the algorithms provided are shown to terminate in finite time if the performance requirements are achievable. Moreover, the intermediate problems are efficient convex optimization problems. When uncertainty is present, we have developed efficient convex relaxations of the (complex) probability optimization problems and have shown how these can be applied to several problems of controller design that have a well defined (small) risk of not achieving the desired performance specifications

A few applications of the results above were studied. In a first one, switched systems were used to model brain waves  in an effort to perform seizure detection. A second one was the use of system identification tools to distinguish between ghosts and targets when using radars in an adversarial environment. Finally, the PIs have started a collaborative effort with behavioral scientists where the objective is to use the control design tools developed to design effective behavioral treatments.
